text:
Anyone has worked with Chromecast ?

Some of channel video have .m3u8 format not able to playe.
<@U0JBN2DV2>: you should add a firebase tag to that
How would you guys implement a drag n drop system?
Currently I have a relativelayout with a view in it. But in order to do anything you have to have a draglistener on the relativelayout
and a ontouch listener (which starts the drag) on the view.
Meaning that I can only do something with when your finger is over the view :thinking_face:
I’m thinking of just putting a onTouch event on the relative layout. And catching down & up in there.
And then write the whole drag n drop system myself.
It’s just calculating positions, if you down anywhere, the view should jump to that position. In that case if you wish to “drag” you still can.
I need to do something similar for a resizer, my idea was to measure the distance dragged from down to up. And increase view accordingly.
quick survey of the room: how many ~3000 line fragments do you have in your codebase?
<@U0LATL928>: when I came in, all were over 3000. Now it’s about 3 I haven’t had a chance to refactor.
<@U0LATL928>: fragments as in android.app.Fragment or codefragments?
A fragment that does a sh*tload of stuff is about 1000 lines
0. i work on apps that have 20+ fragments and i don’t think i’ve seen one over ~500 lines
I know, I want to destroy^whold accountable this 3rd party offshore group that built all this _incredibly awful_ code
There are so many lessons here
Yeah, that’s what’s happens with outsourcing code.
<@U0LATL928>: can you nuke the codebase or not?
I have a flavor that I have to port some code over to, where I can sanitize and fix it
I’m relatively new to android, but wanted to see if 3k+ line codefiles are common, and I was pretty sure they’re not
well they are common, not in this community maybe, but I’d say 90% of apps on the playstore are written using shit as glue between spaghetti they call code
thanks for listening to me bitch, it helps :simple_smile:
that’s what this slack is for
I’m almost certainly going to have to share more gems as I come across them

attachments.fallback: [February 8th, 2016 8:42 AM] lordlobo: ’s that start like this ```String newString = “” + [whatever]```

text: if it was an int, I can understand why (well sorta)
I can empathize, I guess is the right word
even if you did ```String newString = intValue.toString();``` you still don’t need the leading “” (or am I wrong?)
you’re wrong if intValue is an `int`
you could do String.valueOf(int) or Integer.toString(int)
but `int` doesn’t have methods, it’s a primative
and if you pass that int to a lot of android methods, you’ll get a crash because Android takes ints for resources
this code is making my mind slip a little. probably a decent into madness
Yeah because code like this surely has a great set of tests :stuck_out_tongue_closed_eyes:
I should also note, these ‘professionals’ started this project with eclipse. I had to force them into Android Studio.
i’d say you dont, you’re part of the problem, no?
the ‘bonus round’ here is that my boss is dead-set AGAINST TDD
which doesn’t make a ton of sense, but whatevs
but writing tests helps you refactor
<@U0LATL928>: mine is completely against test and finds them useless, tho I still write them when I catch time
but tbh in most shitty apps you can’t write tests
think about tests as part of development
include them in time estimations and so on
boss/manager/whoever even doesn’t need to know about tests
don’t get me wrong, I’d prefer TDD in most cases. As long as the tools are good.
yeah I stopped asking to be allowed to write tests / practice TDD
I’m not going to ask if I’m allowed to use `for`-loops either
that’s not their job to tell you
I just realized <@U091EBYSU> and <@U04TK850N> share a common theme to their profile pics
i think its just they both don’t have mouths
and they are covering it up.
good news everyone - within this nearly 3000 line peice of crap fragment class, I have found one method that’s  OVER 1300 lines long!
this is, of-course, achieved by copy-and-pasting a giant block of code for 15 distinct controls without simplfying the structure of that block
Probably couldn’t handle your scale? This is the facebook app right?
<@U0542GLTE>: stole the words right out of my mouth
tyty. lol. Bash’em whenever I can
Hey guys, what are the best image processing libraries that you've used? And why do you like them?

I’m using Retrofit for hitting various RESTful URI's in the cloud, and right now I have some really verbose code because lets say I want to download a list of users, well first I need to make sure my session is still active by verifying the token I have in cache. If for some reason that token is no longer valid, I have to go to the authentication service to get a new token. So for every RESTful service call I make, I do this little dance where I first check my session and re-authenticate if necessary, THEN hit the service I’m interested in. I’m using RxJava so this is all done through observables. I was wondering if anyone had any recommendations for how I can do this cleanly, and if so, do they have any links I can take a look at?
I’ve used picasso without much issue
glide is pretty good too, has a bit more bells and whistles to it
<@U04U5KS3Z>: No OAuth…it’s just a basic authentication that returns a token that is then passed along with each request

you’re doing MVP or something?
the token is checked on the client or the backend?
do you get an expiry time with those requests?
<@U0DC95VCP>: if the server returns an error on request. You can add an ErrorHandler in Retrofit and get a new token there and retry the connection.

text: <@U0ETA9WHH> tru! tho it’s different compression, it is more efficient

Glide basically has everything and more that Picasso has, just is more focused on memory management than Picasso. If you want to have it be a bit more pretty, you'll just have to add some 'settings' to your image builder.
Thanks guys! Glide seems like the overwhelming winner here
<@U04VA47NB>: we dare not mention such heresy
we love you ari, but enough is enough!
<@U0542GLTE>: you tried doing that via sync adatpers?
Also, Glide vs Picasso is eh
It all depends on the API
And what you want to reszize
and how big are the images, cuz picasso breaks at a certain point
Glide does look better when cold starting an app
Your server should be handling that for you
and resizing based on whatever image sizes you want

text: yeah I see it sometimes on my phone when sharing images
I used Picasa for its image viewer
yeah i see, was wondering why a service implementation instead of that
nice, tho i managed to do similar with sync adapters, after wrapping away the boilerplate
Yeah, but the session instance here is used all over the place, as is sessioncache
So it was about the necessity of the project
I’m late but I use Picasso still
I'm more interested in the caching & memory management part of things
and from what I've heard, Glide has good mem management
Picasso delegates it’s caching to Okhttp (as it should)
Glide has different defaults. Dunno if i’d call it “good"
I like that Glide has better documentation than Picasso
I assume everyone references this article <http://inthecheesefactory.com/blog/get-to-know-glide-recommended-by-google/en>
which is so much FUD that it pisses me off
Glide “has better memory management” because it defaults to RGB565
which is fine if your images are not using alpha, etc.
or dont give a crap about image quality.
but they say you can change that if you don't like it
well you can change it in Picasso too
eh it's easy enough to fix
its just one example of it not being any better
Picasso caches the fullsize, so you only need to DL once
yeah I just read that bit
also, dunno if you care but Picasso is like 1/5 as many methods
but if I needed gifs or something, I’d definitely say to use glide.
glide also handles exif, if you need that feature
I've had to use it recently
so yes, that would be nice
stupid samsung phones were rotating photos
<@U060Q7J2Y>: yeah don't really need it for gifs
unless there’s been an update, it was an intentional omission - <https://github.com/square/picasso/issues/846#issuecomment-70008034>
